ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained an overview of key topic in physical organic chemistry with plenty of examples of how these concepts have manifested themselves in scientific literature.
How to think about the most likely conformation or organic molecules and their importance in drug applications.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The biggest strength of the course is definitely the content and Prof. Jorgensen's authority on the subjects he is teaching. Some may see the fact we only had two problem sets as a positive, but I found this really detracted from my experience because my opportunities to practice were few and far between. There was a big lack of clarity as a result of this with regard to what we were going to be assessed on, which made these exams really difficult to prepare for. I also don't see the purpose of having two exams a week apart from each other, I honestly would have rather just had one.
The course was not very engaging and lectures were difficult to follow

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: It depends. If you're really fascinated by concepts in physical organic chemistry and are driven to learn more about it, you should take the course. If not or you're still trying to figure that out, Jorgensen's half of the course probably is not worth taking.
If you are confident in your chemistry ability then the course would be fine but its a lot of self-teaching and highly dependent on your prior knowledge
